abstracts.cdata!:
This project is essentially a Government
            and Malagasy project, successfully implemented by Malagasy
            without any external long-term assistance. In Madagascar, it
            was the first project of this scope and size working with
            communities and nongovernmental organizations. One important
            outcome is that it has clearly demonstrated the benefits of
            such an approach on a scale which goes beyond previous
            attempts by pilot type operations. Given the project
            objectives as interpreted above, the outcome of the various
            components can be rated as satisfactory. Other key lessons
            learned include: The project's effectiveness was
            reinforced by the "contracting approach." Strong
            national leadership and continuity is very important for the
            success of any community nutrition project. The community
            should know from the time of entry that the program will not
            go on forever: a satisfactory community exit strategy should
            be defined and should gain acceptance. A successful program
            design includes program flexibility and training.
            Implementation plans and manuals of procedure facilitate a
            speedy and smooth implementation. Promoting behavioral
            changes through well-designed and conducted information
            campaigns (IEC) are important to sustain project objectives.
            An IEC strategy and program designed by nationals having an
            intimate understanding of local behavior and customs can
            have a high impact at low cost. The delegated contract
            management approach works well and at a reasonable cost in
            rural and urban areas.
